The Cottage was envisioned by Mrs. Shouse to be a place where artists could create music and other performing arts as they spent time being immersed and inspired by their surroundings. However, the Cottage was lost to a fire in 1979 and was never rebuilt.
data.audioDescription:
(168 words)
The Composers Cottage Site is located southeast of the Filene Center. From the southeast corner of the West Parking Lot, proceed east through the pedestrian tunnel and continue uphill one hundred fifty feet. Turn right and travel five hundred feet uphill to a lush, sunken oval garden area surrounded by a traffic circle. Continue southeast to Parking Lot 4, on the south side of the Filene Center.
From Parking Lot 4, southeast of the Filene Center, follow the dirt trail at the east end of the parking lot that leads east into woods. At about two hundred feet follow the brown sign with a green arrow pointing east and labeled: Composer's Cottage Picnic Area. The sign also has an arrow pointing right to the Kids Park Trail and left to the Track Trail.
About one hundred feet north is an approximately two-hundred square foot opening in the forest. Two picnic tables are set in the clearing, which is framed by a rectangle of logs laid on the ground.
END OF DESCRIPTION

data.title: Dirt Filling
data.listingDescription: A solid foundation is vital for a fortification, especially underneath the heavy cannons. With the exception of the water cistern at the center, the base of the fort is filled in with dirt and construction debris. There was no need for extra storage space or to spend the time and resources to construct it of solid stone. The outer walls provided adequate protection against enemy attacks. The dirt filling provided enough support for the living space and observation tower as w

images.altText: A Bobcat tractor digs into the gundeck of the fort.
images.caption: Early restoration attempts were sometimes invasive, as shown with the Bobcat tractor. Excavations found that the interior of the fort was filled with nothing more than dirt and construction debris. Today excavations, archaeological research and repairs are completed with less invasive techniques.

data.bodyText:
A solid foundation is vital for a fortification, especially underneath the heavy cannons.

With the exception of the water cistern at the center, the base of the fort is filled in with dirt and construction debris. There was no need for extra storage space or to spend the time and resources to construct it of solid stone. The outer walls provided adequate protection against enemy attacks. The dirt filling provided enough support for the living space and observation tower as well as heavy cannons on the gundeck.

data.title: Frazee House Panel
data.listingDescription: Explore the architecture of the Frazee House. The Frazees were a Western Reserve pioneer family who became successful during the canal era.

images.altText: Paved path leads past a graphic panel to the white side door of an L-shaped brick house. Four window
images.title: Frazee House
images.caption: Side view of Frazee House with the Towpath Trail in the distance.

data.bodyText:
From 1825 to 1827 Stephen and Mehitable Frazee and their children built this brick house with their own hands and ingenuity. They dug the foundation, made the bricks, and framed in the building using local materials. The design was inspired by illustrations in Asher Benjamin’s popular 1806 stylebook, The American Builder’s Companion. The Frazees chose elements of the Federal style, something that was familiar to them. This style emphasizes balance and symmetry. For the Frazees, the house symbolized success. Although they initially had financial losses when the Ohio & Erie Canal cut through their property, this new transportation route ultimately was a benefit. They went from living in a wilderness outpost to being established farmers. They may have used part of their settlement from suing the state of Ohio to purchase the hardware and glass used inside.

Minor changes have been made to the house during the past two centuries. The second owner, John Hynton, added a kitchen “ell” in the back, with a woodburning stove. The Frazees had most likely cooked on the hearth. Later residents added electricity and a toilet. However, the room layout has changed very little, a testimony to the timeless Federal style.

More recently, the building has shown signs of shifting. In 2011 the National Park Service closed the Frazee House to monitor cracks in the foundation and assess damages. The building remains closed pending funding to stabilize and re-open the historic building.

To learn more, cross Canal Road to the Towpath Trail where there is a second graphic panel about the Frazee family. A short distance north, additional exhibits explore life at the nearby Alexander-Wilson Mill. For a more rugged hike, pick up the Sagamore Bridle Trail at the base of the driveway and turn left to follow it northward. To head south, go straight across the wooden bridge and beyond before veering off to the left.
data.audioDescription: Frazee House. 392 words A wayside graphic panel sits at the back, right corner of this red brick house. The house is in the shape of an “L” with the longer front being two stories and the smaller rear wing being one story. The front part has a pair of chimneys at either end. The rear wing has a single chimney at the back. A granite slab forms a step at the door into the back wing. Paved paths lead from the panel to the door and around the back of the house to doors on the other side of the rear wing and into the main house. A parking lot is to the left of the panel. At the back of the parking lot is a small restroom. The graphic panel shows a picture of the house from the front, showing the central door with windows on either side and along the upper story. Text on the panel reads, "Symbol of Success. This house reflects Stephen and Mahitable Frazee’s transition from being subsistence pioneers to successful farmers. They may have come to the Cuyahoga Valley as tenant farmers as early as 1811. Within 10 years they were able to buy more than 600 acres. The Frazees built this substantial brick house in 1825-27 on a prominent hillside site. Both were signs of success – this family was here to stay. The Frazees based many of the house’s Federal-style features on Asher Benjamin’s book ‘The American Builder’s Companion.’ A popular 1806 style guide, the book did not include how-to-do-it instructions. Ultimately the Frazees built their home with bricks they made themselves using local materials and local knowledge.” A quote from the book reads, “Strength, convenience, and beauty, are the principal things to be attended to.” At bottom right is a façade and floorplan from the book, showing a plain, rectangular house with small wings at either end. The caption reads, “The Frazees were inspired by Asher Benjamin’s plan for a country house. What similarities do you see? Notice the boxy shape and how the windows, chimneys, and roofline are balanced and symmetrical.” At top right are images of two fragments from dishes, both covered in decorations including flowers and classical-shaped vases. The caption reads, “Fragments discovered by archeologists indicate the dishware was imported, probably on the canal, and typical of the middle class.” End of description.

quickFacts.value: Frazee House is one of the two oldest houses in Cuyahoga Valley. It has remained relatively unchanged since Steven and his family built it by hand in 1825-27 with little more than a style book. The house is a monument to the Frazees’ transition from a subsistence Western Reserve family living on the frontier to a prosperous canal-era farming family.
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: Ohio & Erie Canal District, Ohio and Erie Canalway National Heritage Area, Ohio to Erie Trail, Industrial Heartland Trail Network, National Register of Historic Places

data.title: Frazee House Towpath Panel
data.listingDescription: From the Towpath Trail, gaze across the canal to the Frazee House, built with handmade bricks in 1825-27. It still dominates the landscape, much as it did during the canal era.

images.altText: “Frazee Family” panel; behind it, across a water-filled canal and a road, a historic brick house.
images.title: Frazee from Towpath Panel
images.caption: Towpath exhibit highlights the Frazee House across the road.

data.bodyText:
Stephen and Mehitable Frazee moved into the wilderness, perhaps as early as 1811 from further east in Ohio. Here they raised their family, farming to put food on the table. Initially they probably lived in a log-style cabin further up the hill along the former road. Early tax records indicate that the Frazee family had horses and a cow. After the Ohio & Erie Canal was built here in 1825, we see a shift in the Frazees’ practices. Tax records after 1827 show Stephen Frazee had up to 8 “milch” (milk) cows—about 7 more than a subsistence family. They probably shipped out excess milk and dairy products on the canal, getting paid in cash. In time they became respected members of their community, raising children who become teachers, ministers, and farmers.

The house has been a home to a farming family for most of its existence. Stephen Frazee sold it to John and Elizabeth Hynton. After John’s passing in 1865, Elizabeth and a son-in-law nurtured and grew one of the more profitable farms in the area. After Elizabeth Hynton passed, the house only changed hands a couple of times before being purchased by the National Park Service. In the 1980s, preservationists and historical carpenters stabilized the house. Time is beginning to take its toll though, resulting in the temporary closure of the house in 2012. It waits again, for more work, as it stands guard over the valley.

Cross Canal Road to get a closer look at the architecture, use the vault toilet, and read a second graphic panel.
data.audioDescription: Audio Description: Frazee Family. 307 words Across the canal and scenic byway from this wayside graphic panel is a plain, red-brick, two-story house. It has a brown shingled roof with a pair of brick chimneys at each end. A white door sits in the middle of the front with a pair of white-trimmed windows on either side. The upper story has five windows. The canal in front of the panel has water in the bottom and is crossed by a flat wooden bridge at the right. Trees surround a field on the other side of the towpath with a horse trail along the edge of the field. The panel has an illustration of the house from the right side, revealing a one-story wing at the rear with another chimney at the back. The winter scene features snow and bare trees. A man in a jacket and hat carries a bucket at the rear of the house. Text on the panel reads, “Impact of the Canal. Stephen and Mehitable Frazee experienced both the challenges and benefits of the Ohio and Erie Canal. They arrived in this area in the early 1800s, when it was sparsely settled. They lived in a log cabin, cleared forests for farmland, and were mostly self-sufficient. Canal construction in 1825 flooded their fields and destroyed their crops. The family had to buy feed, flour, and seeds for several years. Stephen sued the State of Ohio and won a settlement of $130. The Frazees built the brick farmhouse across the road about the same time the canal opened. The canal provided the Frazees and all the local farmers with an effective means to send their products to market. “Both the house and canal symbolized greater prosperity. What are positive and negative consequences of public works where you live? “Cross the road and explore the Frazee House’s exterior.” End of description.

quickFacts.value: Park at Frazee House, 7733 Canal Road, Valley View, Ohio 44125 and cross the street to the Towpath Trail.
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: Frazee House is one of the two oldest houses in Cuyahoga Valley. It has remained relatively unchanged since Steven and his family built it by hand in 1825-27 with little more than a style book. The house is a monument to the Frazees’ transition from a subsistence Western Reserve family living on the frontier to a prosperous canal-era farming family.
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: Ohio & Erie Canal District, Ohio and Erie Canalway National Heritage Area, Ohio to Erie Trail, Industrial Heartland Trail Network, National Register of Historic Places

data.title: Gleason Farm Panel
data.listingDescription: View the historic Gleason Farm as you travel the Towpath Trail. It remains a working farm, part of the park’s Countryside Initiative program.

images.altText: Gleason House and its big red barn are across the canal on Tinkers Creek Road.
images.title: Gleason Farm Panel Photo
images.caption: Gleason House and its information panel.

data.bodyText:
Farming was once the main occupation for most valley residents. Across the road is the Gleason House, built in the 1850s. Edmond Gleason owned and operated a sawmill and quarry in the area. While this was a farm, he likely leased it out to someone else who worked the land.

Preserving the rural landscape is part of Cuyahoga Valley National Park’s enabling legislation. The park does this by working with its partner Countryside to manage the Countryside Initiative. This innovative program leases historic farm properties such as this one to farmers practicing sustainable agriculture. Today this property is operated as Canal Corners Farm.
data.audioDescription: Gleason Farm. 332 words Here is a wayside panel facing a section of the canal with water in the bottom. On the other side of the canal is the scenic byway. Across the road at the left is a two-story, stone house. The front is painted cream and it has a gray shingled roof. Long porches with white railings extend across the front at both the ground level and along the second floor. Wide steps lead up to the main entrance on the second floor. A dormer window extends from the roof above the front door. To the right of the house along a side road is a long red barn with a metal roof. The other side of the towpath is lined with trees with fields behind. The right side of the graphic panel has a photograph of the Gleason House from around 1900. The house is missing the dormer above the door and it has a chimney at the right end. A tall-sided wagon sits on the sloped, unpaved road in front of the house. The caption explains that the owners of the house were part of the extended family that ran a store and tavern at the Canal Exploration Center. At lower left is a photograph showing the front of the house covered with scaffolding. The caption reads, “The National Park Service rebuilt the house’s foundation and restored stonework and woodwork in 2005.” Text at top left reads, “Preserving Rural Scenery. The 1850s house and barn across the road remained in the Gleason family for over 100 years. Edmund Gleason ran a sawmill in Bedford and by 1854 owned over 300 acres here. Records indicate he may not have farmed the land himself but leased it to others. Today some of the Gleason acreage is farmed as part of the Countryside Initiative. This program preserves rural scenery and revitalizes the valley’s farming heritage. Farmers lease historic properties and use sustainable practices to limit their impact on the environment.” End of description.

quickFacts.value: Park at Canal Exploration Center, 7104 Canal Road, Valley View, Ohio 44125 and hike south on the Towpath Trail.
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: The Gleason Farm is one of the few historic farms still operating in Cuyahoga Valley. Farming had been the way of life for hundreds of families. The national park preserves that heritage through the Countryside Initiative leasing program.
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: Ohio & Erie Canal District, Ohio and Erie Canalway National Heritage Area, Ohio to Erie Trail, Industrial Heartland Trail Network
quickFacts.name: Designation

data.title: Lock 39 Trailhead Information
data.listingDescription: This is the northernmost trailhead within Cuyahoga Valley. From here, visitors can explore the Towpath Trail south into the national park or north into Cleveland Metroparks. Across the parking lot is an access point for the Cuyahoga River Water Trail and a pedestrian bridge to Rockside Station.

images.altText: A three-sided kiosk and bench are at a fork. The trail on the right is beside a water-filled canal.
images.title: Parking Lot From Towpath at Lock 39
images.caption: This information kiosk is along the Towpath Trail, downhill from the Lock 39 Trailhead parking lot.

data.bodyText:
Nearby Lock 39 is one of over 200 locks that once operated along the Ohio & Erie Canal. With its heyday in the mid-1800s, the canal was part of the early transportation system in the young United States. People and goods were flowing between East Coast cities and the rural heartland, pushing America’s borders westward.

Today this area is a hub of recreational activity. Over a century ago, residents of greater Cleveland began looking for relaxation and recreation outside of crowded cities. Excursion canal boats, trains, and even horse drawn carriages brought visitors into the Cuyahoga Valley. You can now explore the Ohio & Erie Canal via the adjacent Towpath Trail by bike or by foot. You can see the valley too from the windows of the Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad. Across the parking lot is a bridge to Rockside Station and an access down to the Cuyahoga River Water Trail. Visit this information kiosk to get oriented and pick your adventure.
data.audioDescription: Lock 39 Trailhead. 470 words A three-sided, covered kiosk sits at the side of the smooth, unpaved Towpath Trail next to a small bench. One side has a bulletin board with current news, while the other two sides have graphic panels. On the other side of the path is the canal, water at its bottom and a steep, brush-covered bank on the other side. A wooden post next to the canal has a small sign that reads “Lock 39, Towpath Trail.” Going left on the path leads to Cleveland Metroparks. Going right leads to the Canal Exploration Center. Trees and bushes line the side of the path opposite the canal. One of the graphic panels is titled “Welcome to Cuyahoga Valley National Park” and features a map of the park stretching along the Cuyahoga River with your current location at the northern end of the park marked. Text on the panel reads, “Since the 1800s, the Cuyahoga Valley has been a place where people from nearby cities relax in nature. Building on this tradition, locals worked tirelessly to preserve what is now Cuyahoga Valley National Park. Created in 1974, the park protects open countryside, a canal that helped build the nation, and the river that sparked the Clean Water Act. “Lock 39 Trailhead. The Rockside name probably comes from the many small quarries that once dotted this area. Travel by foot, bicycle, or rail to learn about Ohio’s transportation history. Canal Exploration Center is 1.75 miles south on the Towpath Trail. The CanalWay Center of Cleveland Metroparks is about four miles north. From the nearby trailhead parking lot, cross the footbridge to reach Rockside Station. This is the northern starting point for the Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad.” The third side has a panel titled “Ohio and Erie Canalway” with a large black and white photograph of three mules pulling a canal boat on the canal. Smaller photographs show the Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad, a group of children riding bicycles on the towpath and the scenic byway that winds through the valley. A long map down the right side shows mileage between trailheads on the Towpath Trail. Text on the panel reads, “The Ohio and Erie Canalway celebrates the first 110 miles of a waterway that helped the nation grow. Dug by hand from 1825 to 1832, the Ohio and Erie Canal was the first canal west of the Appalachian Mountains. It connected Lake Erie to the Ohio River, providing a key link in an interstate shipping route. People and products flowed across America. Canal towns became major commercial centers. Ohio grew in population and wealth. Today you can explore the lasting impact of this historic public works project. Travel along the Canalway’s three spines. Discover how culture, recreation, and natural scenic beauty are being revitalized by this national heritage area.” End of description.

quickFacts.value: This is a gateway to Cuyahoga Valley National Park to the south and Cleveland Metroparks to the north. Nearby Lock 39 is a remnant of the historic Ohio & Erie Canal.
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: Ohio & Erie Canal District, Ohio and Erie Canalway National Heritage Area, Ohio to Erie Trail, Industrial Heartland Trail Network, National Register of Historic Places

data.audioDescription: Curry Village services are located in one building complex, with a layout shaped like a big square, with only two sides of the square being utilized. As you approach the building from the Curry Village Parking area, there is a raised deck that extends along a majority of the front side of the building that requires going up a few steps. Circular, sometimes umbrella'd, picnic tables are randomly placed on the deck. Placement of services are as follows, from left to right, The Mountain Shop and Yosemite Mountaineering School entrance, the Meadow Grill order and pick-up windows, and The Curry Village Gift Shop. Near the gift shop are another set of steps and a ramp that leads down to a walking path that goes around the side of the building to more services. Another raised deck extends across almost half of that side of the building. After climbing a few steps onto the deck, more circular picnic tables are randomly placed about. Placement of services are as follows, from left to right, The Pizza Patio order and pick-up windows, the Curry Village Bar, and the entrance to go inside the Curry Village Pavilion to access Mother Curry's Kitchen, the Coffee Corner, indoor seating, and restrooms.

data.audioDescription:
The Yosemite Valley Lodge complex is made up of three main buildings that are situated in close proximity to each other, and form a triangular shape, around an outdoor courtyard.

The building behind the front desk office, which is connected by a breezeway, is where, from left to right, the Mountain Room Lounge, Cliff Room, and Yosemite Valley Lodge Gift Shop are located.

The Mountain Room Lounge dining area consists of one large room with high ceilings and wood paneled walls. Three out of the four dining room walls are predominantly made of glass panels from floor to ceiling. The wall that is not glass, has a large mirror in the center of it, and wood paneling and shelves of liquor bottles on both sides of the mirror. This bar counter, has several bar stools and extends most of the length of this wall. Flat screen TVs hang from behind the bar and a few around the room. In the middle of the dining room is a large fire place with benches surrounding it. Tables and chairs are randomly situated throughout.

data.audioDescription:
The Yosemite Valley Lodge complex is made up of three main buildings that are situated in close proximity to each other, and form a triangular shape, around an outdoor courtyard.

The building to the west of the front desk office, connected by a breezeway, is where, from left to right, the Base Camp Eatery, Starbucks, Garden Terrace, and Mountain Room are located.

The Mountain Room entrance shares an enclosed porch with the Garden Terrace entrance. The porch is made of large timber beams and posts that rise up into a high-pitched roofed. The doors to the Mountain Room are made of heavy wooden panels. A sign to the right of the entrance reads The Mountain Room. The dining area consists of one large room with high ceilings and exposed wooden beams, wood paneled walls covered in photographs that are each emphasized with their own accent lights. data.title: Lock 37 and Flood Gate
data.listingDescription: Lock 37 was once a busy location with a tavern, mill and floodgate. A small parking lot on nearby Fitzwater Road provides access to the Towpath Trail.

images.altText: Two people walk a paved trail, pausing to read graphic panels. On the left is a water-filled canal w
images.title: 20181023 TTW-L37 wayside NPS Arrye Rosse
images.caption: Lock 37, on left, and a flood gate, on right, with Alexander/Wilson Mill in the background.

data.bodyText: Wherever a lock was built, boats had to stop to lock through. Businesses often sprang up at these spots, making use of the stopped traffic or the power of the falling water. Here at Lock 37, there was a tavern and a store. During the mid-1800s, the Alexanders built a mill across from this tavern. In time, that mill was sold to the Wilson family, who still own the business today. Regulating a constant four feet of water in the canal is a challenge. From the beginning, engineers struggled with too much or too little water. Near this busy lock is a flood gate that allows excess water to be released from the canal into the nearby Cuyahoga River. Even today this lock remains busy—being near the Towpath Trail, the Wilson Feed Mill, and the access road to the Fitzwater Trainyard.
data.audioDescription: Audio Description. Lock 37 and Water Control Gate. 432 words. At this point on the Towpath Trail near the concrete marker for mile 14 there are two small graphic wayside panels. On the canal side is one titled “Lock 37” which sits next to the old lock which has water at its bottom. The sides of the lock are weathered, worn concrete covering the upper part and the underlying blocks visible below. The gates are gone, but there is a stationary barrier, stone at the bottom, wooden beams above, which blocks the downstream end. There is no guardrail at the edge of the 10-foot-deep lock. The graphic panel features an artist’s illustration of a freight boat in the lock in 1863. A large white building beyond the lock on the left is the Alexander/Wilson Mill, still there today partially hidden by trees. The illustration shows several buildings on the right, now gone, which were the Vanoucek tavern, store, house and barn. Text on the panel reads, “Family Businesses. Canal locks attracted businesses to serve canal boat crews, locals, and farmers. Here at Lock 37 the Vanouceks ran a tavern and general store and the Alexander family operated a gristmill. A spillway allowed excess water to flow around the lock. The mill used the spillway’s waterpower to grind grain into flour and livestock feed.” The other wayside panel, titled “Floods and Repairs,” is down the path to the right as you face the lock. It sits on the other side of the path near the river which lies close to the canal at this point. Just past the panel is a wooden bridge without railings that crosses a small channel which carries water between the canal on the left and the river on the right. Four gear-like mechanisms line the right side of the bridge which control openings in a gate below. Text on the panel reads, “Regulating Water Level. Canal engineers did not foresee the intensity of valley floods and later added structures to control water levels. Here a National Park Service worker adjusts a floodgate built in the early 1900s. Look closely at the actual structure. Can you see the small gates below where the worker is standing? Gates are opened to drain off water so canal repairs can be made here or downstream. During floods, excess water is diverted to protect the canal from being damaged. A waste way takes the water to the Cuyahoga River.” The photograph on the panel shows a man in a National Park Service uniform using a long metal rod to turn one of the gear mechanisms. End of description.

quickFacts.value: Park at the unmarked Fitzwater Parking Lot, Fitzwater Road west of Canal Road, Independence, Ohio 44125 and walk south on the Towpath Trail.
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: Lock 37 stands beside the historic Wilson Feed Mill, one of the last mills still operating on the Ohio & Erie Canal. A nearby flood gate helps control the water level.
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: Ohio & Erie Canal District, Ohio and Erie Canalway National Heritage Area, Ohio to Erie Trail, Industrial Heartland Trail Network, National Register of Historic Places

data.title: Lock 38 at Canal Exploration Center
data.listingDescription: What is a canal lock? Stop here to learn about the mechanics of these boat elevators. If you are lucky to have water in the canal on a summer weekend, you might see volunteers demonstrating how Lock 38 works.

images.altText: Four people in historic costume stand on the left side of a water-filled stone lock.
images.title: 20140514 CEC-L38 Grand Opening lock demo
images.caption: Lock demonstration in front of Canal Exploration Center.

data.bodyText: Outside of Canal Exploration Center is a reconstruction of Lock 38. On summer weekends when conditions allow, volunteers demonstrate how a lock operates. Canals were designed as waterways without waterfalls or a current. Locks were built to raise or lower canal boats wherever there was a significant change in elevation. A lock works much like a toy in a bathtub. If a boat needs to go up, water is let in through butterfly valves in the upstream gate. The chamber is filled until it is level with the upstream water. If the boat needs to go down, water is let out through butterfly valves in the downstream gate. When the water is low enough to match the downstream level, the downstream gates can be opened. To fit inside the locks on the Ohio & Erie Canal, boats could be no more than 75 feet long.
data.audioDescription: Lock 38. 470 words This wayside graphic panel sits at the downstream end of the lock. Behind the exhibit, a small wooden footbridge crosses to the other side. To the right of the bridge are the heavy wooden gates that close this end of the lock. Each gate has a long wooden beam attached along its top and extending out to the side. A similar pair of gates sit at the upper end of the lock to the right. On the other side of the towpath is a white-frame building that held a tavern and store. To the left of the lock is a road and bridge crossing the canal. That road ends at the scenic byway on the far side. The inside walls of the lock are made of concrete-covered stone blocks. The tops of the walls are even with the ground and there is no guardrail. At the left side of the panel, text reads, “Lock 38 is one of the few restored, working locks along the historic Ohio and Erie Canal. Locks are like elevators – they raise and lower boats between levels. State engineers designed 44 locks to deal with a 395-foot rise in elevation from Cleveland to Akron. Heavy wooden gates enclose the boat-sized stone chamber. Lock operators added water to the chamber to raise a boat headed upstream. They drained out water to lower a boat headed downstream.” The right side of the panel has a drawing of one of the wooden gates with its beam extending over the lock wall to the right, a man pushing on the end. Arrows indicate features of the diagram. The caption next to the end of the beam reads, “Balance beam. A long beam balances out each heavy gate. The beam makes it possible to open and close the gate by hand.” At the bottom of the gate is a small door called a wicket. The caption reads, “The gates cannot open unless the water level is the same on both sides. A valve at the bottom of each gate, called a wicket, lets water in or out.” At the top of the gate is a long shaft called a wicket stem connected to the wicket below. The caption reads, “Boatmen opened and closed the wicket using a large wrench to turn the wicket stem and pivot the wicket.” The gate itself is called a whaler gate. The caption reads, “Two gates at each end keep the water in the chamber.” At lower left is a photograph of the lock empty of water, showing the smooth vertical walls and a flooring made of wooden beams. The caption reads, “In the 1980s National Park Service workers restored Lock 38 to how it looked in 1907. This was just after the state lined locks with concrete. Notice the wooden floor.” End of description.

quickFacts.value: Canal Exploration Center, 7104 Canal Road, Valley View, Ohio 44125
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: Lock 38 is a reconstruction of the original lock outside what is now Canal Exploration Center. Also called Twelve Mile Lock, this is the last functioning lock that remains on the Ohio & Erie Canal.
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: Ohio & Erie Canal District, Ohio and Erie Canalway National Heritage Area, Ohio to Erie Trail, Industrial Heartland Trail Network, National Register of Historic Places
quickFacts.name: Designation

data.title: Sam E. Johnson Sr. Cabin
data.listingDescription: For five years (1867 - 1872) this cabin was the home of Samuel Ealy Johnson and his wife Eliza. While Sam ran the family's cattle business, Eliza attended by hand to virtually every detail of running the ranch. She hauled water, spun wool, made clothes, cooked meals, and tended the animals. Self-sufficiency was a must; the nearest store was in Blanco, a day's ride away. The Johnson cabin is typical of the "dogtrot" cabins that were once common in Texas. The shaded breezeway-t

images.altText: A log cabin with two rooms separated by a breezeway sits on green grass under a blue sky.
images.title: Sam Ealy Johnson Sr. Cabin
images.caption: The weathered log cabin of President Johnson's grandparents

relatedParks.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Lyndon B Johnson

data.bodyText:
For five years (1867–1872) this cabin was the home of Samuel Ealy Johnson and his wife Eliza. While Sam ran the family's cattle business, Eliza attended by hand to virtually every detail of running the ranch. She hauled water, spun wool, made clothes, cooked meals, and tended the animals. Self-sufficiency was a must; the nearest store was in Blanco, a day's ride away.

The Johnson cabin is typical of the "dogtrot" cabins that were once common in Texas. The shaded breezeway—through which a dog could easily trot—provided storage space and much-needed relief during the hill country's blistering summers. The west wing, nearest you, was built first, in 1856; Sam Johnson added the east wing about 1868.
data.audioDescription:
Samuel E. Johnson, Sr. Cabin exterior. 279 words

The weathered, gray cabin consists of two rooms separated by a wide breezeway. The walls are made of rough-hewn wooden beams with concrete filling the thick gaps. The wood-shingled roof stretches over both rooms and extends both front and back to cover wide wooden porches. Two stone steps in the middle lead up to the porch in front.

Each of the rooms has a stone chimney at the outer end, side windows with plain wooden shutters, and a single door opening onto both the front and rear porches. The rooms have simple furnishings which may be viewed through the glass covering the open doorways. The righthand room includes a bed covered with a quilt, a cradle, a wash stand, and a spinning wheel. The room on the left has a table with small stools, shelves on the walls with pans and mixing bowls, and a screen-fronted cabinet holding dishes, cups and glasses.

Benches sit on the front porch on either side of the breezeway. On a right-side wall about 18 feet from the front steps past the doorway is a button, which may be pressed to hear a brief history of the cabin narrated by Luci Johnson, younger daughter of President and Mrs. Johnson.

In front of the cabin on the right is a large stone well covered by a thick stone slab with a round hole in the middle, now covered with a sheet of acrylic. A ramp alongside the right side of the cabin provides wheelchair access to the back porch.

The back porch looks out over grassy fields. To the right behind the cabin is a smaller log building and farther back is an outhouse.

End of description.

data.title: Sentinel Bridge Parking Area
data.listingDescription: Delight in a leisurely stroll onto Sentinel Bridge and gain an astounding view of Half Dome, especially in the evening when the reddish-orange alpenglow is brought on by the setting sun. Views of the Merced River, Half Dome, and Yosemite Falls through Cook's Meadow, are just a few of the benefits of parking here.

images.altText: A line of cars are parked in a parking lot next to an open meadow that showcases a view of a tall waterfall.

data.bodyText:
Delight in a leisurely stroll onto Sentinel Bridge and gain an astounding view of Half Dome, especially during the alpenglow, when a reddish-orange glow is brought on by the setting sun.

Views of the Merced River, Half Dome, and Yosemite Falls through Cook's Meadow, are just a few of the benefits of parking here.

Half Dome
The profile of Half Dome has become a recognizable symbol of Yosemite. Millions of years ago, the granite block of Half Dome was larger, but there was never a matching other half. Passing glaciers undercut the base, and slabs of rock fell away, leaving a sheer face.

Merced River
The Merced River is a National Wild and Scenic River. Its waters originate in the melting snow of Yosemite's high country in the southeastern portion of the park. The river plunges over Nevada and Vernal Falls, then meanders across the flat Yosemite Valley. It continues its journey down the Merced River Canyon and spills into the San Joaquin Valley. Early Spanish explorers named the Merced River for Our Lady of Mercy.

Hours:
Year-round

Getting Here:
Located on Sentinel Drive, just over the Sentinel Bridge, and before Yosemite Village Day Use Parking.

Rules & Regulations:
Sleeping in your car or RV overnight in a parking lot or along the side of the road is not allowed.
You may store food inside your car (out of sight, with windows completely closed) only during daylight hours. Empty your car of all food, drinks, coolers, toiletries, and trash after dark. Even an empty candy bar wrapper is enough temptation to entice a bear to break into your car. Vehicles containing food after dark may be impounded and/or cited.

Accessibility:
There are designated accessible parking spaces available.
data.audioDescription:
The Sentinel Bridge Parking area is a prime spot to experience Yosemite Falls. The north side of the parking lot is lined with a wooden fence that separates the sidewalk from the large open meadow that shows views of Upper and Lower Yosemite Falls. Bus stop #11 stands at the southeast side of the parking lot. Four benches, a green recycle bin, brown trash bin, and a small, wood, shelter are all by the bus stop. Further south from the bus stop, a crosswalk leads across the street to the Sentinel Bridge. A few wayside exhibits are located in the parking lot, along the meadow.

The first exhibit panel is titled Ecotones: Life on the Edge, and has a faint background photo of a small patch of meadow, containing long grasses and sedges, surrounded with pine trees. Panel text reads, the zone where two habitats merge is called an ecotone. The meadow/forest ecotone is visible here. The water-saturated meadow gives way to the oaks and towering conifers, which can't survive in flood-prone areas. The greatest diversity of wildlife exists in these transition areas where a variety of food and shelter is present.

The Changing Landscape - By the 1860s, hotel owners were converting meadows to pastures, gardens, orchards, and hay fields. They suppressed fires because they threatened wooden buildings. They also channeled the Merced River to control flooding and drained boggy areas of the Valley.

Black and white photo: Black and white spotted cows graze in an open meadow with towering cliffs surrounding them.

Caption: Yosemite Valley, 1918.

Meadows in Peril - Only a century ago the meadows of Yosemite Valley were far more extensive than they are today. With the right balance of water, fire, and soil conditions, a meadow can survive indefinitely. But with the altercation of the water table and fire cycle in the Valley, the natural balance was lost.

Black and white comparison photo 1: An aerial view of a meadow below the iconic Half Dome shows larges patches of open meadows with trees scattered here and there.

Caption: Yosemite Valley Meadows, 1899

Black and white comparison photo 2: An aerial view of a meadow below the iconic Half Dome shows dense stands of trees with only a few small patches of meadow showing.

Caption: Yosemite Valley Meadows, 1991

Next to the first wayside exhibit, a second one is titled Meltdown, and has a faint background photo of a waterfall coming over a tall, granite rockface. Panel text reads, the high-country snowpack is Yosemite's reservoir. As the snow melts in the spring, torrents of water cascade over Yosemite Falls (on the cliff before you) and over dozens of other waterfalls.

Upstream, shallow soil on granite slopes absorbs very little water, Once the snow is gone, usually by late summer, most of Yosemite's waterfalls quickly dwindle.

Black and white comparison photo 1: A close up view of a wet rock face.

Caption: Yosemite Falls - Autumn

Black and white comparison photo 2: A thin stream of water falls over a large granite rock wall. White ice has built up on the rock face on both sides of the thin waterfall. At the bottom of the fall, a pile of snow has built up.

Caption: Yosemite Falls - Winter

Black and white comparison photo 3: Two waterfalls are stacked on top of each other. The upper fall is full of water and the lower fall has a slightly more narrow, shorter, stream of water.

Caption: Yosemite Falls - Spring

Black and white comparison photo 4: The two waterfalls that are stacked on top of each other have dwindled down to a think, hair-like strand of a waterfall.

Caption: Yosemite Falls - Summer

Quote: "You should stop a while...a little below the head of the fall beside the enthusiastic throng of starry, comet-like waters to learn something of their strength, their marvelous variety of forms, and above all their glorious music, gathered and composed from the snow-storms, hail-, and rain- and wind-storms that have fallen on their glacier-sculptered, domey, ridgy basin." - John Muir, The Yosemite, "How Best to Spend One's Yosemite Time"

Lost Arrow - Seasonal changes affect more than just the waterfalls. Water seeping into cracks and fissures in the cliff face freezes and expands in winter, wedging off blocks of stone. This action constantly reshapes Yosemite Valley. Lost Arrow, the isolated granite pinnacle to the right of Yosemite Falls, was once a part of a solid wall of rock.

Black and white photo: A granite spire is shown from above, rising up like a tower.
Caption: Lost Arrow from above

A nearby sign reads, flood water level, 11pm, January 2, 1997. A double-sided arrow points from left to right. The sign itself stands over six feet high.

data.title: Mudcatcher
data.listingDescription: Across the canal here, visitors can see the manmade Mudcatcher Falls. The stone abutment was built to hold back soil and debris from entering the canal. From this vantage point, visitors can travel north or south on the Towpath. To the north, in less than a tenth of a mile, the Valley horse trail will veer off to the left. In early spring, visitors may be lucky enough to see a bald eagle from this trail.

images.altText: In a half circle bump out, a square graphic panel overlooks a canal choked with soil. On the opposit
images.title: Mudcatcher
images.caption: Here Gaulley Run, an intermittent stream, flows over the stone Mudcatcher and into the canal.

data.bodyText:
Maintaining a constant four feet of water in the Ohio & Erie Canal was a challenge. From the beginning, engineers struggled with too much or too little water. They built aqueducts and culverts where large streams crossed the manmade waterway. Some smaller, seasonal streams such as Gaulley Run were allowed to feed into the canal, replacing water lost to leaks and evaporation. Once farmers cleared trees from uplands fields and hillsides, erosion became a problem. Each year, maintenance crews used to dredge the canal to remove sediment swept in by storm water. This mudcatcher “caught” soil and debris floating in Gaulley Run and held it in a basin behind the wall. Since canal operations stopped, this basin has filled in. After heavy rains, mud and gravel flow over the opening and into the canal. Periodically, the National Park Service must dredge this section of canal. Look for accumulation under “Mudcatcher Falls.” This manmade waterfall flows during all but dry weather. A graphic panel explains the scene. 
 

From here, visitors can travel north or south on the Towpath Trail. To the north, in less than a tenth of a mile, the Valley Trail veers off to the left. A half mile to the south, there are more engineering stories to explore, as well as restrooms, in the Station Road Bridge area.
data.audioDescription: Mudcatcher. 241 words The towpath here winds between the canal and the river with woods on either side. On the canal side is a graphic wayside panel titled “Mudcatcher, Filtering the Flow.” On the far side of the canal, a stream runs down between two steep slopes towards the canal and river. Between the slopes is a dam-like structure made of large stone blocks. An opening in the middle allows the water to fall in a short waterfall into a pool below when the stream is running. Text on the panel reads, “Soil washing into the canal created an ongoing problem. Storms eroded upland fields and hillsides left treeless by farmers. Engineers usually built culverts under the canal to carry streams into the Cuyahoga River. Here the intermittent Galley Run flows directly into the canal. A mudcatcher – the stone structure in front of you – held back the soil in a basin. Crews dug out the mud and debris during the dry season. “With its basin full of muck, the mudcatcher no longer functions. Do you see sediment building up in the canal today? The National Park Service periodically needs to dredge this watered section.” The panel has a photograph of the scene in front of you with the parts labeled. Arrows indicate the steep sides of the ravine cut by the stream, the historic dam-like mudcatcher structure itself, and a pile of dirt and gravel between the mudcatcher and the canal. End of description.

quickFacts.value: Park at Station Road Bridge Trailhead, 9141 Riverview Road, Brecksville, Ohio 44141. Cross the bridge and walk north on the Towpath Trail.
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: The mudcatcher may be the only structure of its kind left along the Ohio & Erie Canal. It is an example of the engineering needed to maintain a constant level of water in the canal.
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: Ohio & Erie Canal District, Ohio and Erie Canalway National Heritage Area, Ohio to Erie Trail, Industrial Heartland Trail Network
quickFacts.name: Designation

data.title: Ritchie Ledges Panel
data.listingDescription: The Ledges create a high point in the valley uplands. Learn the basics of their geology at the Ritchie Ledges wayside. It describes how periodically fast-moving streams flowed through a steamy swamp about 315-320 million years ago. The streams brought sand and pebbles that formed the Sharon Sandstone and Conglomerate rock that we see today.

images.altText: “Ritchie Ledges” panel stands along an unpaved trail surrounded by tree trunks and fallen leaves.
images.title: Ritchie Ledges Panel
images.caption: A panel along the Ledges Trail explains the rock formation’s geology.

data.bodyText:
The Ledges create a high point in the valley uplands. Discover the basic geology at the Ritchie Ledges graphic panel. It describes how water and weathering shaped the rock.

About 315-320 million years ago, the area was steamy swamp. Periodically fast-moving streams dropped sand and pebbles here. Over time, this material was compacted into rock called Sharon Sandstone and Conglomerate. Erosion has carved the rock into the forms you see today.

Like a sponge, the rock absorbs rainfall between the grains of sand and pebbles. This water makes the Ledges cooler and moister than its surroundings. More northern plants and animals can thrive here. Look for evergreen eastern hemlock trees and listen for the cheery, buzzy song of black-throated green warblers. Take a moment to enjoy the coolness and beauty of this microclimate.

Life on the Ledges is fragile. Mosses and ferns cling to sand and pebble crevices. Please help us protect this fragile life by enjoying the Ledges from the trail. A moment of rock climbing, which is not allowed, can erase years of growth.

Learn more about the geology of the Cuyahoga Valley.
data.audioDescription: The Ritchie Ledges. 372 words This wayside graphic panel sits at an intersection where two trails on top of the Ledges plateau cross each other. All around are thick woods, deciduous trees mixed with evergreen hemlocks. A sign post tells us that the Ledges Shelter is one-quarter mile to the left as you face the graphic panel, the Octagon is one-third mile straight ahead, while going in the other direction leads to the Ledges Trail, a long loop which circles this entire geologic formation. At the opposite side of the crossroads is a bench. The panel has a map of the entire Ledges, an oval shaped area with your current location a third of the way from the right end. The Ledges Shelter lies to the left with the Overlook and a trail to Kendall Lake at the far left. At top of the map is the trail to the Octagon. At bottom, a trail passes the Ice Box Cave and skirts the rocky cliffs along that edge. At far right, a side trail leads to the Happy Days Lodge. Text on the panel reads, “As you wander through the unusual environment of the Ritchie Ledges, you will encounter evidence of an ancient landscape, one that has witnessed great changes in climate and terrain. You will be exploring the remnants of primeval stream beds deposited when the area was a steamy swamp 320 million years ago. Over time, these sand and pebble sediments were compacted into rock, now called Sharon Conglomerate. Erosion has carved the rock into the form you see today. Life on the Ritchie Ledges is fragile. Soil on the rocks is thin and root systems are very shallow. Please enjoy the beauty of the Ledges from the trail. A moment of thoughtless rock climbing can erase years of growth.” At upper right is a drawing of small hemlock branches with seed cones at the tips. The caption reads, “The Ledges are cooler and moister than the surrounding area, attracting plants and animals adapted to this microenvironment. Evergreen eastern hemlocks, shown here, are perhaps the most striking of these. They hint of a time when their kind thrived in the cooler, moister climate that followed glacial retreat 14,000 years ago.” End of description.

quickFacts.value: Park at Ledges Trailhead, 405 Truxell Road, Peninsula, Ohio 44264. Hike north past the shelter on the Ledges Trail.
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: The Ledges are an outstanding outcropping of Sharon Sandstone and Conglomerate. Its geology influences the local environment and adds to the park’s plant and animal diversity.
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: Virginia Kendall State Park Historic District; Ohio and Erie Canalway National Heritage Area
quickFacts.name: Designation

data.title: Shag Rock Overlook
data.listingDescription: This overlook just west of Arch Point provides coastal view of the northwest coast, including Shag Rock. Shag Rock reaches 145 feet above sea level, and is about an acre in size. Shag is another name for a cormorant, a marine bird which nests at this location. Stop 5: Arch Point Tour-Geographical Isolation As you near the ridgeline with the island's two highest points, 635-foot Signal Peak and 562-foot North Peak, take a moment to look across the island. You may notice the

images.altText: Aerial image of small island with steep cliffs.
images.title: Aerial, Santa Barbara Island
images.caption: Aerial view showing Santa Barbara Island’s marine terraces. Shag Rock is in center foreground.

data.bodyText:
This overlook just west of Arch Point provides coastal view of the northwest coast, including Shag Rock. Shag Rock reaches 145 feet above sea level, and is about an acre in size. Shag is another name for a cormorant, a marine bird which nests at this location.

Stop 5: Arch Point Tour-Geographical Isolation

As you near the ridgeline with the island's two highest points, 635-foot Signal Peak and 562-foot North Peak, take a moment to look across the island. You may notice the broad, elevated coastal plain stretching in front of you, one of six on the island. These plains are remnants of what geologists call "marine terraces"-ancient shorelines carved flat by wave action and exposed through changes in sea level and tectonic uplift of the land. A future marine terrace (called a wave-cut platform) is being created today by wave erosion at the base of the sea cliffs.

The Channel Islands' first shoreline was created around five million years ago, when compressional forces, caused by the ramming of Baja California into southern California, resulted in the folding and faulting of marine sediments and volcanic rocks (deposited between 15-30 million years ago) and the eventual uplift of the islands. These compressional forces are still ongoing, making this area geologically active today-Santa Barbara Island, as well as the other Channel Islands, continues to be uplifted.

Ever since these compressional forces caused the islands to emerge from the sea, the Channel Islands have been separated from the mainland. And unlike the four northern islands, which were once joined as a single, "super island" known as Santarosae, Santa Barbara Island has never been connected to another neighboring island.

For decades, however, scientists assumed that the northern islands (Anacapa, Santa Cruz, Santa Rosa, and San Miguel Islands) were connected to the mainland by a land bridge, but as bathymetric information (or topography) of the sea floor improved, it revealed that even during periods of lowest sea levels (about 17,000 years ago), the islands still remained isolated by at least four miles of ocean. It is this continuous geographical isolation that has shaped island life.

Santarosae
Although never connected to the mainland by a land bridge, the four northern islands were once part of the Pleistocene 'superisland' known as Santarosae, nearly four times as large as the combined areas of the modern Channel Islands. The dark shaded area on the map depicts ancient coast of Santarosae and California around 20,000 years ago when sea level was 100 meters (approximately 350 feet) lower than it is today. As the ice sheets and glaciers melted and the sea level rose, only the highest parts of Santarosae remained as modern islands.
data.audioDescription:
You are standing near a steep coastal cliff, with an ocean cove below. If you are facing the cove, you are facing west. In the distance, a flat, grassy plateau slopes down into two points that stretch out into the sea, creating another distant cove, but its shoreline is obscured by the closer landform. To the right, or north, and just off shore, is Shag Rock-a large sea rock with a steep shoreline.
A wooden bench, with two "legs" and a wooden plank seat, is near the edge of the cliff providing a splendid view of the right side of the cove. Be careful if you decide to sit on it, as it is covered with white bird droppings. In front of the bench, low wooden railroad tie planks lie on the ground, marking the edge of the cliff
At your feet, the gritty soil has tiny fragments of broken shells and white rocks. Much of the ground is covered with this bare earth, but there are patches of coastal sagebrush, ice plant, and Greene's dudleya, a pale grey-green succulent with thick, fleshy leaves clustered in a rosette shape.

To the east and west are stands of coreopsis, on thick stalks with feathery green leaves and mounds of bright yellow, daisy-like flowers in the spring, and brown, shaggy clumps or dried leaves and blooms in late summer and fall.

data.title: Soda Springs/Parsons Memorial Lodge Tour - McCauley Cabin (Stop 14)
data.listingDescription: The McCauley brothers built this cabin in the 1890s and has since exchanged ownership between the Sierra Club, and the National Park Service. Learn a bit more about the history of this cabin on this wayside exhibit.

images.altText: A wood cabin sits on a hilltop above a meadow. Pointy granite peaks can be seen in the distance.

data.bodyText: The McCauley brothers built this cabin in the 1890s and has since exchanged ownership between the Sierra Club, and the National Park Service. Learn a bit more about the history of this cabin on this wayside exhibit.
data.audioDescription:
This wayside exhibit is the fourteenth stop of 15 on the Soda Springs and Parsons Lodge Tour. A rustic log cabin sits on a small hilltop, overlooking Tuolumne Meadows, the river, and the granite landscape that surrounds it. The front of the cabin has a wooden door with a window, offcentered to the right, and a window with shutters on each side end of the building. There are now windows in the back. The nearby wayside exhibit is titled, The McCauley Cabin, and has a black and white photo on the left, two-thirds of the panel. The photo shows a man, a woman, and two young blonde girls standing in front of them. The young girl to the left is shorter than the girl on right, who is wearing checkered pants. A log cabin home is in the background, with boulders and trees surrounding it.

Caption: The campground caretakers stayed in the McCauley Cabin. As a young girl, Margaret Eissler (in checkered pants) lived here with her family for six summers (1956-1961). Her childhood experience instilled a love for Tuolumne Meadows that influenced all aspects of her life. She later returned as a ranger-naturalist.

Panel text reads, Following Jean Baptiste Lembert's death, the McCauley brothers bought his land for pasture in 1897 and built this cabin. When the land was again put up for sale, Sierra Club members raised money to purchase it in 1912 to keep it uncommercialized.

The Sierra Club opened a small campground, and summer after summer campers returned here to renew their connection with these meadows and mountains. In 1973, the National Park Service bought the Sierra Club property.

Tuolumne Meadows has found its way into many people's hearts. Follow the river. Take some time to explore. Discover for yourself the wonders of these high meadows.

data.title: Lock 39
data.listingDescription: Lock 39 is the northernmost lock in Cuyahoga Valley National Park. It is one of many canal remnants you can see as you walk, ride, or run along the Towpath Trail.

images.altText: Close up of an interpretive panel called Lock 39: Stepping Up and Down.
images.title: Lock 39 Photo
images.caption: The Lock 29 panel with a touchable profile of the locks between Akron and Cleveland.

data.bodyText:
In operation from 1827 to 1913, the Ohio & Erie Canal turned the sleepy village of Cleveland into a major port. Boats carried timber and farm products to Lake Erie and returned with manufactured goods and specialty foods.

Unlike Ohio’s rivers, canals offered a consistent depth for boats to travel and no current. Yet the land they travel through is not flat. Water is travelling north from a high point near Portage Lakes in Akron, down 395 feet to the level of Lake Erie at Cleveland. Whenever the drop of water or land was significant, a lock was installed to move boats up or down. In effect, locks acted as elevators for boats. Water would be let in from the higher side to raise the water level, or let out on the lower side to lower the boats.

Originally locks were made of carved sandstone, and often lined or “puddled” with clay to keep them from leaking. But water takes its toll. During 1905-1906 renovations, this sandstone lock was refaced with a new concrete surface, now also wearing away.

Along the Towpath Trail, a graphic panel describes the function of the locks. At the bottom of the panel is a touchable profile of the 44 stair-step locks between Akron and Cleveland.
data.audioDescription: Here on the canal is an old lock structure. At the side of the towpath near the lock a graphic panel describes the function of the locks. At the bottom of the panel is a touchable profile of the 44 stair-step locks between Lake Erie in Cleveland and the portage summit in Akron. To the right of the panel is a bench made of wooden beams between two concrete bases. Across the path from the canal is an overgrown field backed by woods.  The canal and lock contain water. The sides of the lock are made of stone and concrete. At the left, or northern end, a small footbridge crosses the lock to a grassy area on the other side. The end of the lock closest to the graphic panel is closed with a thick, wooden barrier keeping the water level feet below ground level. On the northern side of the barrier gate, the water is ten feet below the ground level. Exercise caution near the lock as there is no guardrail. Water trickles under the barrier to fall into the deep lock.  The background of the graphic shows a black and white photograph of a functional lock. The view up the lock shows the block walls and water splashing through the partially open, heavy wooden gate at the end. A note tells us that “Canal managers covered the blocks with concrete during a 1905-1906 renovation.” Along the bottom of the panel is a touchable profile with braille labels of the lock system. The edges of the profile can be sharp. Lake Erie at 573 feet is at the left end. Forty-four locks form stair steps up to 968-foot-high Portage Summit at the right end. In between are Boston at Lock 32, Peninsula at Lock 29, and Mustill Store at Lock 15. Text on the panel reads,   “Stepping Up and Down. Locks act like elevators, raising and lowering boats. Most locks along the Ohio and Erie Canal had a lift of about nine feet. It took 44 locks to manage the 395-foot elevation rise between Cleveland and Akron. Canal engineers numbered locks in both directions from Akron’s Portage Summit. In operation from 1827 to 1913, the canal turned the sleepy village of Cleveland into a major port. Boats carried timber and farm products to Lake Erie and returned with manufactured goods and specialty foods.”  End of description.

quickFacts.value: Park at Lock 39 Trailhead, 8000 Rockside Road, Independence, Ohio 44131 and hike south on the Towpath Trail.
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: The Ohio & Erie Canal was once a vital transportation route, connecting Ohio to growing East Coast cities such as New York. Engineers built locks such as this one to manage water flow and to raise and lower boats.
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: Ohio & Erie Canal District, Ohio & Erie Canalway National Heritage Area, Ohio to Erie Trail, Industrial Heartland Trail Network, National Register of Historic Places
quickFacts.name: Designation

data.title: USS Oklahoma Memorial

images.altText: USS Oklahoma Memorial
images.title: USS Oklahoma Memorial
images.caption: USS Oklahoma Memorial

data.bodyText:
Located on Ford Island, an active duty military base. The USS Oklahoma Memorial is only accessible via Pearl Harbor Historic Sites Shuttle, or with an active duty military or escort with trusted traveler permissions. 

The USS Oklahoma capsized at 8:08 A.M., approximately 12 minutes after the first torpedo hit. Hundreds of men were trapped below her decks. They found themselves in a bizarre world turned upside down, in pitch-black darkness, as compartments filled with water. Death came to 429 officers, sailors and Marines, marking the second greatest loss of life at Pearl Harbor.

In 1944, the Oklahoma was salvaged and raised at Pearl Harbor. Because new battleships of greater strength and size had been added to the fleet, she was denied future service and decommissioned. In 1947, she was sold for scrap but sank in a storm while being towed to the West Coast.
data.audioDescription: 429 marble plinths stand at attention in a v formation. Each plinth bears the name of a lost Sailor or Marine.

data.title: USS Utah Memorial
data.listingDescription: On December 7, 1941, Oklahoma's port (left) side was hit by eight torpedoes at the very start of the attack. In less than twelve minutes, she rolled over until her masts touched the bottom, trapping hundreds of men inside and under the water. Four hundred twenty-nine crew members died. Of those trapped inside, only 32 could be rescued.

images.altText: A birds eye view of the USS Utah Memorial with the flag at half mast
images.title: USS Utah Memorial
images.caption: A birds eye view of the USS Utah Memorial with the flag at half mast

tags: world war II in the pacific
data.bodyText:
On December 7, 1941, the USS Utah, moored on the other side of Ford Island and hit by torpedoes at the start of the attack, quickly rolled over and sank. Fifty-eight of Utah's crew died. The ship was never salvaged and remains where it sank in Pearl Harbor.


Currently the USS Utah is not accessible to the general public. 

There are no doctors or nurses on-site. EMS is available and a hospital is nearby. If you have a medical need please call 911.
data.audioDescription: A concrete walkway with railings extends into the harbor for approximately 30 feet and turns left at about 90 degrees paralleling the remains of the USS Utah.

data.title: Tavern and Store Panel
data.listingDescription: Canal Exploration Center was once a rest stop on the Ohio & Erie Canal. The Gleasons ran a tavern and a store in this building in the mid-1800s.

images.altText: A graphic panel and life ring stand ouside a white historic building with a porch and an M-shaped
images.title: Tavern and Store Panel Photo
images.caption: Canal Exploration Center was a rest stop at Lock 38.

data.bodyText:
This building has witnessed many changes through the years. Documents reveal that Ma Parker had her tavern on or near this location by the time of canal construction. Artifacts uncovered here also suggest this was a pre-canal tavern. The original building was the southern half of the structure. By 1841, Moses Gleason bought the property and sold it to his son. Isaac Gleason added the southern part of the building, turning it into a store serving travelers waiting at Lock 38. The Gleason family continued to live here until the early 1900s. After that, the building became a residence and later housed a blacksmith shop. As the building wore down, it became a multi-resident structure.

The National Park Service purchased the property and began historic reconstruction in the early 1990s. In 1996 it opened as Canal Visitor Center. Today it operates as Canal Exploration Center, where visitors can explore Ohio & Erie Canal history through hands-on exhibits.
data.audioDescription: Tavern and Store. 390 words At the side of the wide towpath, to the right of a graphic panel, is a two-story, white-frame building that looks like two houses stuck together. Each side has a peaked gable over its front and dark green shutters at the windows. The left section of the building had a covered porch along its front with a double door in the middle and a window on either side. On the left side of the porch is a bench. A barrel sits to the right of the doors. The ground slopes down along the left side of the building, revealing a stone basement. In front of the left end of the building is a lifesaver ring hanging from a post. The right section of the building has a single door at its left side and two windows to the right. A water-filled lock is on the other side of the towpath with large, functioning wooden gates. Exercise caution near the lock as there is no guardrail. Text on the graphic panel reads, “Canal Rest Stop. In the mid-1800s, the Gleason family ran a tavern and store in this building. Here boat crews and passengers could get something to eat and drink. They also could buy supplies such as tea, sugar, tobacco, needles, and thread. Tour the exhibits in the old tavern-store. Decide for yourself whether building the Ohio and Erie Canal was worth the tax dollars.” The lower right of the panel shows a color illustration of a canal boat approaching the tavern and store on the left. The lock gates stand open to receive the boat. At the rear of the boat is a dark-skinned man in a top hat and long black coat. The caption reads, “John Malvin, a free black from Virginia, became a businessman and civic leader in Cleveland. This scene shows Malvin in about 1853 as the captain of the ‘Auburn.’ His crew included both blacks and whites.” At the bottom left is a photograph from around 1910 of the tavern and store building, looking much as it does today except for a smaller building at the back-left corner. The caption reads, “After the canal era, the building became a residence and later housed a blacksmith shop. Notice that the building on the left – probably a barn – is no longer there.” End of description.

quickFacts.value: Canal Exploration Center, 7104 Canal Road, Valley View, Ohio 44125
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: This twin-peaked structure has been here at least as long as the Ohio & Erie Canal. It originally served as a tavern for passengers weary of canal boat travel. Later it was a store. In the 1900s it became a residence, a blacksmith shop, and then multiple residences.
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: Ohio & Erie Canal District, Ohio and Erie Canalway National Heritage Area, Ohio to Erie Trail, Industrial Heartland Trail Network, National Register of Historic Places
quickFacts.name: Designation

data.title: The Loft at Degnan's
data.listingDescription: The Loft at Degnan's is the perfect place to enjoy Mexican fare, Asian rice bowls, and artisan pizzas. A wide variety of wines and beers on tap are available. The Loft at Degnan's features numerous TVs to enjoy sports and other entertainment. Open year-round, see website for hours. Located in eastern Yosemite Valley, in Yosemite Village.

images.altText: A brown, A-frame building is surrounded by trees and has two circular signs on the side of the building. One sign reads, The Loft at Degnan's, and the other sign reads Degnan's Kitchen.

data.bodyText:
The Loft at Degnan's is the perfect place to enjoy Mexican fare, Asian rice bowls, and artisan pizzas. A wide variety of wines and beers on tap are available. The Loft at Degnan's features numerous TVs to enjoy sports and other entertainment.

Hours:
Year-round,
See website for hours.
